is it right though? if I read the code right, it goes as follows:

if target_tenant of RBAC entry that we remove is "*", then determine the list of tenants that have non-wildcard access_as_shared RBAC entries; and if at least one of bound_tenant_ids (tenants who own objects that are attached to the object the policy entry is declared for) doesn't have a non-wildcard entry, then the removal of the original wildcard entry would lock the affected tenant from accessing his own resource. In this case, we want to block (raise_policy_in_use) wildcard entry removal, and not proceed (return).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Leaving <%net_cidr%> aside, I think we should be careful here. If we were to do this we should take into account things like spine/leaf (and bgp), composable networks and pacemaker_remote nodes.
Fwiw, pacemaker uses the ctlplane network only if there is no network isolation, otherwise it uses the internal-api but you can also override pcsd_bind_addr so it will be tricky to cover all edge cases. 
In any case both ctlplane and internal_api should be isolated and secured vlans so adding the 'source' to the iptables rules is a plus but not mandatory imho.

nova/conductor/manager.py.message:
I know they're not in the existing handling but with the linked bug [1] in mind, I'm thinking we may want to include a few more things in here such as:

* ks_exc.RequestTimeout [2] (server 408) Server closes connection on the client bc client took too long to send a complete request. I have seen this happen when haproxy is involved and things in the environment are slow due to various issues, haproxy responds with 408. Can be transient.

Whether we include this exception depends on whether we are OK to let conductor run in a degraded state with the warning log message being enough to tell the operator they need to investigate their environment. The potential downside of doing that being if the service is "working" operators may not feel motivated enough to investigate their environment.

* ks_exc.GatewayTimeout [3] (server 504) The specific fail case from [1], request times out trying to communicate with the gateway. Can be and is usually transient.

I've seen this one in the gate enough times (example [4]) and I've seen customers hit it. One thing I'll note is that there are likely gaps where other touch points are not tolerating 504 but some patches have landed to enable these cases to retry (example [5]).

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1846820
[2] https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/2445a5df78d808a773ea820505c7af5215c573cf/keystoneauth1/exceptions/http.py#L190
[3] https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/2445a5df78d808a773ea820505c7af5215c573cf/keystoneauth1/exceptions/http.py#L358
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-gate/+bug/1912845
[5] https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/8f4b740ca5292556f8e953a30f2a11ed4fbc2945

> * ks_exc.RequestTimeout [2] (server 408) Server closes connection on the client bc client took too long to send a complete request. I have seen this happen when haproxy is involved and things in the environment are slow due to various issues, haproxy responds with 408. Can be transient.
> 
> Whether we include this exception depends on whether we are OK to let conductor run in a degraded state with the warning log message being enough to tell the operator they need to investigate their environment. The potential downside of doing that being if the service is "working" operators may not feel motivated enough to investigate their environment.

If it's raised separately, I suspect RequestTimeout is what you'd actually get if your network is down and ConnectFailure comes if your network is up but keystone is down. So, agree, that belongs in the same bucket.

> * ks_exc.GatewayTimeout [3] (server 504) The specific fail case from [1], request times out trying to communicate with the gateway. Can be and is usually transient.

Ack, that's the same as timeout, but as detected from a different vantage point, so agree.

now we share a single client between AggregateAPI and API within the same service process. We use the client in AggregateAPI to sync nova aggregates to placement aggregates and updates the aggregate cache in the provider_tree. We use the client in the API to delete instance allocation (local delete) or query for RP existence and traits on RPs.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: I'm wondering if there is only one global client then using that here would also mean that ComputeManager, ResourceTracker and ComputeVirtAPI use the same client instance, the global one. So why do we do it differently here?

Do we have a ComputeManager instance per ironic node? I doubt it. Also for some reason (maybe due to multiple ironic nodes per compute manager) the provider_tree supports multiple roots.

The comment suggest that we need the same client but it does not say when and why we need different clients. If we only know that we need the same client then it would make sense to use the global one.

Could you at least make the comment clearer?

Because of the internal state you mention elsewhere? Perhaps the first part of the comment is wrong, but I assume that if we're managing multiple compute nodes (i.e. ironic) they all need separate copies for the provider tree internal state right?

> Do we have a ComputeManager instance per ironic node? I doubt it.

No, just one of course.

> Also for some reason (maybe due to multiple ironic nodes per compute manager) the provider_tree supports multiple roots.
> 
> The comment suggest that we need the same client but it does not say when and why we need different clients. If we only know that we need the same client then it would make sense to use the global one.
> 
> Could you at least make the comment clearer?

I initially tried this as global, but functional tests fail, likely due to re-using compute node uuids across multiple phases of the tests. When I saw this comment, I think I interpreted it as the opposite of what it says here, implying that the RTs for each node need to be separate (which is, of course, not what it says).

So perhaps this *should* be the singleton and I'll have to figure out what the tests are doing that trip them up?
Per our discussion, yes, gibi is right and I'm going to write a more verbose comment here.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: We only not pass a reportclient at __init__ from the test, the ComputeManager always pass down its own client. So this is safe (depending on the ComputeManager being safe).

nova/conductor/manager.py.message: I think we have one ComputeTaskManager per process. So I think it is not worse than before. The original code also shared the client between parallel Task objects (i.e. two LiveMigrationTask handling different source and dest nodes). So even if that can cause races this change does not make it worse.

nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py.message:
Now this is interesting. This could use the client from the MigrationTask or the LiveMigrationTask it is called from but it does not use that but creates a new one per task. So here in the past we had independent clients per parallel tasks instances. But now we will share a single instance across.

So we need to look at the actual calls.

//later

It seems every call is independent from the shared state in the client. So this is safe. I suggest to took the opportunity to pass the client from the caller instead.
this call does not depend on the provider_tree ✔
this call also does not depend on the provider_tree ✔

nova/limit/placement.py.message: this call does not depend on the internal state so this is safe

nova/quota.py.message: this call does not depend on the internal state of the client so this is safe

nova/scheduler/client/report.py.message:
So this forces nova to use a single client per process while previously there were separate client instances embedded in separate objects for example in the compute API instances. The report client has internal state, the provider_tree. 

So I'm a bit worried that this change might introduce new race condition possibilities via the shared provider_tree instance. I don't have a specific example based on existing code so this is highly hypothetical.

Now I looked through the usage of the report client and as far as I can tell all the calls within the same service is either:
* not depend on the internal state of the client
* use different independent parts of the internal state

So I think the globalization is safe. (In the future we might introduce new calls to the shared client that break this and introduce races).

So if you agree with my observations (see inline comments in the change sites) then I'm fine globalizing the client.

TBH, I had forgotten that there was (so much) internal state in the client until I wrote this patch, which I think is somewhat of a bad decision on our part (although I know why we did it).

The goal here was to avoid the startup cost (and hit) of going to keystone all the time, both because it should be unnecessary and also to reduce the number of places where we may fail to do that because keystone is down at a random time, when we may already have an initialized client.

I could remove the singleton-ness and just keep the "ask me for a client" behavior if you want, but I'd want to know that the provider tree state is important in other places than just in compute. We do this sort of thing in all the other client implementations, AFAIK, so this is increasing consistency otherwise.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: It seems like it might be better to just create an element for Octavia that sets the required selinux policies instead of pulling in this repo and the larger RPM of policies.
You are going to need a element-deps to pull in the pkg-map and package-install elements

I'm not sure I agree on generating it over vendor-provided packaging, since there's no one set of required SELinux policies that would work. SELinux is inherently distribution-specific[1], so we'd have to copy all the per-distro infrastructure in to the elements... and that seems complicated to me, when vendor packaging provides it.

[1] Happy to expand as-needed, but, as a simple example, just compare SSH policies between Fedora/CentOS/RHEL and Ubuntu/SELinux Reference Policy - macros the policy files use during build differ, boolean names for the same functionality differ, type labels differ... they conflict all over the place.

All of that said, I do find it a little strange that we're automatically pulling in a new repository - I'd think the DIB caller should be doing that using a predefined repo file and providing that repo file to DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF or something, but, I don't have any strong opinion about doing it the way Gregory proposed (there might be precedent).
(I could have misunderstood what you meant, too!)
Added Julie; she may also have opinions.

couple of comments - pushing -1 to raise awareness about the questions/remarks. Otherwise, seems legit, and it's a good thing to be able to test SELinux on CentOS based deployments as well. Even setting it to permissive for CS would at least show real denials in the logs, leading to a better comprehension of the issues we may face downstream.

Thank you Greg for that work!

Can we see that one merged? It will be useful in order to squash selinux denials without invading other locations (think "host SELinux" for instance) within tripleo with rules that are only for amphora/octavia.

Sounds good!

elements/openstack-selinux/post-install..message:
You'll need to use '-N' in chroots such as in DIB - 

   semanage boolean -N -m ...

Otherwise, semanage will try to modify the running kernel's boolean (which we don't want; we want it to modify the one on disk in the chroot during the image build). Here's how openstack-selinux avoids doing it:

   https://github.com/redhat-openstack/openstack-selinux/blob/master/local_settings.sh.in#L237

Also, I'm not 100% sure you can look at what booleans are installed in the chroot in this way, or whether you can do it at all.
Why "-N" ? not sure about the actual impact with that option :/.

-N is "Do not reload policy after commit"
https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/semanage-boolean.8.html

As we are building an image in a chroot here, we don't need to update the selinux policies of the host

I think we're okay because of the "if [ "${AMP_BASEOS}" = "centos-minimal" ] || [ "${AMP_BASEOS}" = "fedora" ] || [ "${AMP_BASEOS}" = "rhel" ];" in diskimage-create.sh, but just checking to make sure I understand correctly: this will only be installed on redhat-based systems, so we don't need to worry about whether the 'semanage' command exists, right?

Beside this question, this looks good to me!

that's a fair question, checking in the logs, the package that provides semanage (policycoreutils-python-utils) is installed by the redhat-common dependency:

> Map install for redhat-common: lsof, tcpdump, traceroute, which, ca-certificates, selinux-policy, selinux-policy-targeted, python3-libselinux, python3-policycoreutils, policycoreutils-python-utils, rng-tools

Not sure if we need to add it explicitly in this element

I think this element should be in the amphora namespace instead of openstack to avoid a potential element conflict with DIB elements.
"openstack-selinux" -> "amphora-selinux"
I think we need to declare in this element that semanage is required for the element.

semanage comes as a dependency of libselinux; and libselinux comes as a dependency of openstack-selinux (and any other -selinux package afaik).

Dependency tree is clean imho, no need to do anything more.

I'm not against these changes, however, I think we need first to check if the different IDs is an expected behavior in design or if this simply an unforseen behavior.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I'm against merging global request id to local request id because usage of local request id is beneficial in case a single api call causes multiple internal api calls.

For example when a user requests nova to attach a volume to an instance, nova send api calls to cinder twice, and having only a single global request id does no allow us to separate logs for these two request.
this makes total sense (while having it random does not really)

oslo_middleware/request_id.py.message:
Personally, I don't think we should squash the global request ID into the local request ID. The solution I was thinking of is this:

 +++ b/oslo_middleware/request_id.py
 @@ -48,10 +48,11 @@ class RequestId(base.ConfigurableMiddleware):
          # TODO(sdague): it would be nice to warn if we dropped a bogus
          # request_id, but the infrastructure for doing that isn't yet 
          # setup at this stage.
 +        return gr_id
  
      @webob.dec.wsgify
      def __call__(self, req):
 -        self.set_global_req_id(req)
 +        gr_id = self.set_global_req_id(req)
  
          req_id = context.generate_request_id()
          req.environ[ENV_REQUEST_ID] = req_id
 @@ -62,5 +63,5 @@ class RequestId(base.ConfigurableMiddleware):
  
          for header in return_headers:
              if header not in response.headers:
 -                response.headers.add(header, req_id)
 +                response.headers.add(header, gr_id or req_id)
          return response

It still fails the existing unit test but it would allow projects to use a local randomly generated request ID if they want while returning the global ID in the response if it was provided.

oslo_middleware/tests/test_request_id.py.message: Different IDs seems expected. First, if it's possible, it could be worth to understand why.
yep. but I don't know why different IDs seems expected when global ID was set. Can you help me?

I was going through patches on my dashboard and came across this again and looked to see if I could find the reasoning behind request ID != global ID. I think I found the reasoning in the spec for the feature [1]:

> We would accept an inbound X-OpenStack-Request-ID, and validate that it looked like req-$UUID before accepting it as the global_request_id.
> 
> The returned X-OpenStack-Request-ID would be the existing request_id. This is like the parent process getting the child process id on a fork() call.

It was designed to only reply with the "child" request ID.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/pike/global-req-id.html#oslo-middleware-request-id

nova/api/validation/extra_specs/hw.py.message:
im kind of sad I did not think of this in the spec review but we should not use the term ephemeral to refer to the root disk.

the root disk is just as persistent as a cinder volume

we should have used a term like hw:disk_encrpution_format or hw:local_encryption_format

hw:ephemeral_encryption_format is ambiguous as it could just refer to the ephemeral storage not the root disk.

do you think we should update the spec to use a better term

same for hw:ephemeral_encryption', I would prefer to use hw:disk_encryption',

ack, I agree on more import before reworking.

I have always found the term ephemeral to be mildly offensive or derogatory when referring to nova root disk storage. i.e. it implies that nova is carless with you data and cinder is not.

to me, cinder storage is not any more persistent than novas.
both only exist for the lifetime of the resource that created them (volume or instance) 

cinder storage does not impley that the backen has any addtional resilnce or data integrety properties espically when using nfs to store qcow files like many cinder drivers do. 

so i have alwasy considerd it incorrect to refer to the root_disk as ephmeral unless you also consider every other resouce a instance owns to be ephmeral including its data volume.
i am fine with  "local disk encryption" if others agree we should make this change and its useful to disambiguate.
As far as I'm aware, this has been resolved and we've agreed to stick with this terminology. Will ask Sean to drop their -1

In the flavors and the block_device_mapping REST API doc we use the term "local" compared to "volume" and use the term "root disk" compared to "ephemeral". So I think the "local disk encryption" is the closest terminology we can have for this feature to include both the root disk and the ephemeral disk handled by nova.

> im kind of sad I did not think of this in the spec review but we should not use the term ephemeral to refer to the root disk.
> 
> the root disk is just as persistent as a cinder volume
> 
> we should have used a term like hw:disk_encrpution_format or hw:local_encryption_format

I dunno, IMHO the use of the word ephemeral is not wrong referring to storage that only exists during the lifecycle of the VM (as opposed to cinder volumes/remote storage [not created by nova] that continues to persist after the VM is destroyed).

I googled a bit and found it seems a pretty standard use:

* https://help.dreamhost.com/hc/en-us/articles/217701757-What-s-the-difference-between-ephemeral-and-volume-boot-disks-

* https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.6/storage/understanding-ephemeral-storage.html

* https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/ephemeral-volumes

> hw:ephemeral_encryption_format is ambiguous as it could just refer to the ephemeral storage not the root disk.

It's not ambiguous in that it is meant to encrypt all of the ephemeral disks, not only the root disk. It is indirectly mentioned in the spec:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/yoga/approved/ephemeral-storage-encryption.html#populate-ephemeral-encryption-blockdevicemapping-attributes-during-build

But ... I realize it *is* ambiguous if there is a cinder volume attached with delete_on_termination=True. In this scenario we would not be encrypting the cinder volumes data and they will be deleted when the VM is deleted. So perhaps this is reason enough to change it.

> do you think we should update the spec to use a better term
> 
> same for hw:ephemeral_encryption', I would prefer to use hw:disk_encryption',

Personally I think "disk encryption" is ambiguous because it could mean any disk attached to the VM including cinder volumes. If we change the term, I think "local encryption" or "local disk encryption" is more clear.

I think it would also be worthwhile to get additional input from more reviewers before changing everything.

extra specs are not part of the micro versioned api. i.e. adding or extending 
extra specs does not require a new microverion

with that in mind the fact that this will track the currently defined set of encryption formats and update automatically when we add new ones is probably the correct approach.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Need to fix this.

I later had a change of mind on this

I think we should be renaming the image and flavour extra spec to remove the word ephemeral and replace it with disk

For completeness, what I replied on IRC earlier today [1]:

> [12:47:16]  <melwitt> sean-k-mooney[m], stephenfin: wrt the naming, I wanted to give everyone a break before bringing it up again 😬 but ... I had thought more about it and thinking about it in the context of the other extra spec/image prop names, I thought "hw_disk_encryption" does seemingly fit better https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1220d53c2fd6231bb569a54f004a0e858536e970/nova/objects/image_meta.py#L347-L351 but as you pointed out, there's a
> [12:47:16]  <melwitt>  chance that users might anyway think it could be referring to cinder volumes as well (?). none of the names are a slam dunk really :(

Looking at those other properties: hw_disk_bus, hw_disk_type, those are understood to only mean local IIUC. So "hw_disk_encryption" would fit nicely in that regard.

To be clear, I'm not advocating one vs the other. I will keep it as hw_ephemeral_encryption unless people think hw_disk_encryption would be better.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2022-08-09.log.html#t2022-08-09T19:47:16

hw_disk_bus, hw_disk_type, also apply to cinder volumes including boot form volume.
the hw_disk_bus form the root disk image metadata is appplied to all volumes nova or cinder that are attached to a vm.

i do prefer hw_disk_encryption but i would also prefer if it applied to all volumes (root, ephemeral, swap and cinder). since this is only going to apply to root and ephmeral volumes i can live with hw_ephemeral_encryption. swap i think is clearly an oversite and i would like that to be covered at some point but lets focus on the planned/approved scope of the spec and deal with swap when everything else works.

Tested it, looks good.
I did more tests, the notifications.info queue appeared empty because the events were consumed by barbican. Disabling barbican-keystone-listener in devstack fixed this issue.

I added some docs to clarify oslo_messaging_notifications options which are required. LMK if this didn't make matters worse :)

I also attempted to replicate the issue with default notifications topic, but it worked as expected in my case (notifications.info topic was created in '/' vhost when first notification is sent).

Thanks for the documentation. I think it is useful. However, I must say I see the same behavior as Gregory in my devstack environment. Any topic works, but the default "notifications" topic doesn't and I see no messages in the notification.info queue. I don't know why, but I don't think that it's specific to this change.

> Thanks for the documentation. I think it is useful. However, I must say I see the same behavior as Gregory in my devstack environment. Any topic works, but the default "notifications" topic doesn't and I see no messages in the notification.info queue. I don't know why, but I don't think that it's specific to this change.

I was able to replicate this issue in a devstack/amphora environment (thank you for the help). What I found is that, without setting the driver for oslo_messaging_notifications in octavia.conf, the topic is not created and the notifications are not sent. This is expected since the default driver is None. I added this section to the example octavia.conf with notes about requirements. When this option is set, e.g. to messagingv2, the notifications.info topic is created as expected. Note that this takes place when the message is sent, e.g. for octavia.loadbalancer.create.end event. Let me know if this clears up the issue for you. And thanks for reviewing!

If we are cleaning up the transport we need to clean up everything else as well.

> TRANSPORT.cleanup()
> NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT.cleanup()
> TRANSPORT = NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT = NOTIFIER = None
Makes sense. I'll get that updated.
Not sure if the Octavia team wants to raise here. When this was implemented they specifically asked to initialize here instead of raising an exception like other projects do.
I would either raise an exception or just call init. Adding clean could lead to some real weird and difficult to troubleshoot race conditions. Personally I think it's fine to use raise here.

Ok, no problem. The reason I raised here as opposed to running init method again is to avoid initializing another TRANSPORT. One option to avoid this without raising an exception would be to run cleanup before init here. Does that sound like it would be acceptable?
Probably safe to just check TRANSPORT here instead.

swiftclient/client.py.message: No, it's exactly the same as existing behavior. We can debate about what the right way to handle this situation is, but this can't be worse than where we are today on master.

i'm not familiar with the format of these responses

https://github.com/NVIDIA/swift/blob/d8af3d7a0db2609fc1a0805a8d592ba4e2d9e120/swift/common/middleware/bulk.py#L716-L717

is the leading slash always included in the LHS of the error tuples?

	>>> '//foo/bar'.lstrip('/')
	'foo/bar'

... hopefully you can't have a conainer name with a slash in it!

> is the leading slash always included in the LHS of the error tuples?

It comes from the "name" stored in the SLO which has always included the leading slash. See https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.29.1/swift/common/middleware/slo.py#L1280 which can trace its history back to https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/1.8.0/swift/common/middleware/slo.py#L270

SLO is defensive to it not being there, though (maybe there was some in-review version that allowed a name like "foo/bar" to be stored?), so I figure the client should be, too. See https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.29.1/swift/common/middleware/slo.py#L478 and https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.29.1/swift/common/middleware/bulk.py#L455 for example.

> hopefully you can't have a conainer name with a slash in it!

No, you cannot -- split_path() will always break the path up on the slash.

Deleting the only NS record in the zone means BIND will not know where to go for the zone transfer (I.e. doesn't know where miniDNS is anymore).

See the log here: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/82751988c6c04690952dc8d0b4628eaa/log/controller/logs/bind9.txt#2819
So this check is showing it removed in the Designate DB, but BIND is refusing to update the zone on the BIND side as the zone it's trying to transfer in is invalid.

web/src/containers/project/ProjectVarian.message:
I think that's *technically* correct (though maybe confusing), since in opendev we add every opendev-hosted project to the check pipeline with an empty jobs list (in the tenant config project using a ".*" project stanza).  We do that so that new projects can get syntax error reports with their first zuul.yaml changes.

In other words, that is conveying the information "this project stanza configures this project to participate in the check pipeline but does not configure it to run any jobs".

Maybe there's another way we want to convey that information though.

It might be nice to check that jobList has proper content before pushing the row. Looks like on opendev projects get an empty check jobs list for some reason. This isn't a regression though so a followup is fine.

zuul/ansible/2.9/library/command.py.message: Someone that runs Zuul on windows (and other remotes) will need to chime in, but is this platform independent? I don't actually know if the console streamer works at all on those platforms. It may be the case that this is already linux/unix specific.

That disables streaming on a winrm connection, but it doesn't address streaming to a windows host over an ssh connection.  I don't know if anyone does that, and I don't know if it's possible.  My guess is "no" to the first and "yes if you have a full posix (eg cygwin) environment" to the second, but I have not researched this.  However, I think the use of os.devnull is good enough for our purposes here.  FWIW, we also assume "/tmp" exists and don't do any special platform handling for that.

zuul_stream.py already exits with no streaming on windows; see

I've just rebased it onto origin/master to get the ball rolling. Would like see some love on this review and get into merged soon.

There's the potential for a race condition for clusters which have older clients, which should be more of an issue for the older releases of Ceph. I think this change is okay for the newer releases of Ceph, but  older releases could maybe be paired with a config option. It is release-note worthy.

config.yaml.message:
in this context what would be the ceph version(s) that are considered "old clients"?, these are the versions the CVE lists[0], should we include them in this description?

[]0 https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/security/CVE-2021-20288/#fixed-versions

hooks/ceph_hooks.py.message: I'm not convinced that this will only be run for a new cluster - won't this also get executed if a new mon unit is added to an existing deployment?
Only if the new unit is also the leader (note that there's an is_leader check inside this function as well
Just wondering: Shouldn't this be moved slightly up ? There are some paths that can cause an early return and I'm not sure if toggling this option should be affected by that.
if we don't have the fsid or monitor secret, we can't change this setting anyway :-D
There's an additional one when checking that the `fsid` and `monitor-secret` were set, but I imagine the same thing applies.
The only early return I see in this section is related to bootstrapping have failed, in which case there's nothing we can do with this either

hooks/utils.py.message: probably WARNING level since according to the docstring this operation would fail on clusters that don't support this.
Now the users would be opting-in to this behavior via juju config, so if insecure reclaim couldn't be toggled this should be logged at a higher level.
The value passed to this function is the charm setting "disable-global-reclaim".  It would help readability for this to be named "disable_requested"

if disable_requested*

Also, I might suggest checking that there are no clients with versions prior to these:

    Pacific v16.2.1 (and later)
    Octopus v15.2.11 (and later)
    Nautilus v14.2.20 (and later)

I'd recommend if there are clients registered that are younger than this, set blocked state "some registered clients don't support global_id_reclaim, see 'ceph versions'" and require an action to force the setting or have user change the config opt to false.
This parameter is no longer available. It should be removed from the doc strings.

As identified in a comment to James, there's a small race window here in which the new unit is selected as the leader and the existing deployment does not have all clients upgraded. The corresponding CVE has been fixed for about a year now and many environments would be required to upgrade to apply it due to their own security policies.

However, many is not all and so there is still a bit of a risk of stopping all clients. I think in newer Ceph releases/charm releases for Ceph - this change is perfectly fine. I think in some of the older releases where this is more likely to be an issue, we should consider providing a boolean config option "allow-insecure-global-id-reclaim" which defaults to False (this can pair with this change by just adding a clause to the if is_leader() check here).
